intro: Dicranolepis disticha, commonly known as the mountain holly or false holly, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the family Ericaceae, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or well-drained soils in woodland or mountainous regions. Its botanical features include small, clustered flowers that bloom in spring and dark, glossy foliage that remains throughout the year. Dicranolepis disticha is often used in horticulture for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in acidic soil conditions.
